s.text: The Journal also reports that NBC honcho Warren Littlefield suggests his network, looking at post-Seinfeld, ratings, uh, shrinkage, is actively considering merging with a cable company (to get a piece of subscriber fees) or TV studio (to get a piece of syndication fees).
USAT explains that the Saturn strike authorization--voted for by 96 percent of the 5,000 workers who cast ballots--means that the plant could be struck with five day's notice.

USA Today leads with more bad news for GM: On Sunday, Saturn workers voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike.
USAT explains that the Saturn strike authorization--voted for by 96 percent of the 5,000 workers who cast ballots--means that the plant could be struck with five day's notice.
The LAT , which also fronts the story, quotes the company's CEO saying this is not an actual strike vote and that so far the plant's schedule has not been changed.
"They're specifically trained," says one agent's lawyer, "not to pay attention [to] what's going on."
The paper explains that although members must pay the companies the cost of a first class ticket for such flights, their actual cost can be tens of thousands of dollars more.
So more complicated ideas have been proposed: retinal scans or numbers made from such personal information as date of birth and the latitude and longitude of one's hometown.
So more complicated ideas have been proposed: retinal scans or numbers made from such personal information as date of birth and the latitude and longitude of one's hometown.
If it's drug abuse to take a pill simply to look virile, the piece wonders, why isn't it illegal to take one to become virile?
If it's drug abuse to take a pill simply to look virile, the piece wonders, why isn't it illegal to take one to become virile?
